Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46534  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
February 2013 
 
 
 
Investment Loan and Grant Disbursement Seminars 
for Developing Member Countries 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  T. de Longuemar, Finance and Risk Management

Assistant Controller  H. Fukukawa, Loan Administration Division, CTL

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Disbursement is a vital part of the project cycle and a critical factor in successful project 
implementation. Consequently, the Controller's Department (CTL) has been providing capacity 
development seminars on disbursement for developing member countries (DMCs) since 1990. 
The  investment  loan  disbursement  seminars  have  been  conducted  for  staff  of  executing 
agencies,  implementing  agencies, ministries  of finance,  and government  audit  offices. The 
seminars  have  focused  on  enhancing  the  understanding  of  executing  and  implementing 
agencies, and application of disbursement procedures of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
The seminars have also aimed to resolve disbursement-related issues faced by executing and 
implementing agencies in their respective projects.  
 
2.  So far, DMCs have provided positive feedback on previous seminars and, at the same 
time,  CTL  disbursement  operations  have  also  benefited.  Staff  members  of  executing  and 
implementing agencies who attended the seminars were able to submit improved withdrawal 
applications by applying knowledge gained from the seminars. It is worth noting that quality 
withdrawal  applications  contribute  to  timely  transfer  of  resources  to  DMCs  and  to  project 
implementation.  
 
3.  The demand for training seminars on investment loan and grant disbursement from 
DMCs such as Central Asia, the Greater Mekong Subregion, and the Pacific, People’s Republic 
of China, India, Myanmar continues to increase. Based on CTL’s past experience and on 
increasing ADB operations, it is expected that further demands from other DMCs may arise 
during implementation of the capacity development technical assistance (TA). The demands 
from  the  DMCs  noted  above  are  attributed  to  issues  such  as  recent  resumption  of  ADB 
operations  in  Myanmar,  revision  of  the  ADB  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook  in  2012,  high 
turnover of project disbursement staff, and lack of institutional capacity. 
 
4.  As  part  of  ADB’s  response  to  the  DMCs’  demands,  concurrence  of  respective 
governments  is  secured  in  the  early  stages  of  seminar  preparation.  The  government  is 
consulted on and informed of the objectives of the seminar, logistical arrangements, financial 
resources available from ADB, and other assistance needed. Seminar participants are invited by 
the government, in consultation with CTL.  
 
5.  In the past, seminars were funded from small-scale regional TA projects.1 Capacity 
development  TA  of  $225,000  has  been  financing  the  seminars  since  late  2011,  with  an 
expected completion date of 30 September 2013.2 As of 21 January 2013, the TA had an 
uncommitted balance of $2,506. This amount is not enough to meet the current demands from 
the DMCs; these will be provided for under the proposed capacity development TA. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 3  
 
                                                
1  ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance for Loan Disbursement Seminars. Manila (TA 5789-REG); ADB. 2003. Technical 
Assistance for Disbursement Training Seminars for DMCs, 2004–2005. Manila (TA 6165-REG); ADB. 2006. 
Technical Assistance for Disbursement Training Seminars for DMCs, 2006–2008. Manila (TA 6348-REG); ADB. 
2003. Technical Assistance for Training and Enhancing Loan Accounting System of OCR Public Sector Borrowers 
and Executing Agencies. Manila (TA 6141-REG); and ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Disbursement, Loan 
Accounting/Servicing Training and Seminars for DMCs. Manila (TA 7508-REG). 
2   ADB. 2011. Disbursement, Loan Accounting/Servicing Training and Seminars for DMCs. Manila (TA 7897-REG).  
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 February 2013.

2 
II.  ISSUES 
6.  Lack  of  institutional  capacity  is  the  main  issue  encountered  by  executing  and 
implementing  agencies  of  various  DMCs.  This  involves  lack  of  understanding  or  previous 
experience of the ADB investment loan and grant disbursement procedures. The capacity issue 
causes submission of substandard withdrawal applications to ADB. Such application quality 
hinders the timely transfer of loan or grant funds to the DMCs and successful implementation of 
the project.  
 
7.  Based on CTL’s interactions with governments in past seminars, institutional capacity 
issues can be attributed to various causes. One of the common ones is high turnover of 
experienced project staff handling disbursement, e.g., in Mongolia and other DMCs in Central 
Asia and the Greater Mekong Subregion. The staff concerned move to the private sector for 
opportunities  which  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  cannot  match.  As  long  as 
turnover is an ongoing issue, the gap in institutional capacity continues. This gap is filled by new 
staff who have limited or no experience with ADB disbursement procedures. Such skills and 
knowledge gaps often contribute to the problems encountered by CTL during implementation of 
projects. Without  provision  of  timely  intervention  measures,  such  as  regular  and  proactive 
capacity development on investment loan and grant disbursements, lack of institutional capacity 
is expected to have a negative impact on project implementation.  
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  impact  will  be  improved  mobilization  of  loan  and grant fund  transfers to  DMC 
governments.  
 
9.  The outcome will be enhanced knowledge of executing agency staff on ADB policies and 
procedures related to financial administration of projects. Achievement of the outcome derives 
from (i) conducting trainings on ADB investment loan disbursement procedures and practices, 
updating the knowledge of participants; (ii) conducting knowledge-sharing forums on country- 
and project-specific disbursement issues, in conjunction with issues resolution; (iii) sharing ADB 
best practices on loan disbursements; and (iv) supporting and sharing the seminar resources 
with the executing and implementing agencies for further training of project disbursement staff, 
including those at the lower levels of the fund flow chain such as counties and provinces.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  It is estimated that 25 seminars and workshops will be carried out with an estimated 750 
participants.  The  targeted  DMCs  are  Group  A  DMCs  (those  with  access  to  the  Asian 
Development Fund only), and Group B and C DMCs that have requested or are likely to request 
a  seminar  based  on  CTL’s  experience.4 The  expected  participants  are  (i)  finance  and 
accounting  staff  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  who  are  directly  involved  in 
disbursement, and (ii) representatives from ministries of finance and government audit offices. 
Resource speakers will be drawn mainly from Controller Department’s Loan and Administration 
Division and disbursement unit staff (for resident missions with a delegated disbursement unit). 
Additional resource speakers will be invited from ministries of finance to speak on counterpart 
                                                
4  For a full listing of countries, see ADB. 2011. Classification and Graduation of Developing Member Countries. 
Operations Manual. OM A1/BP. Manila (section E).

3 
 
fund contributions and from government audit offices to speak on general audit issues from the 
audit of ADB project financial statements.  
 
11.  The seminar will cover topics such as  
(i)  loan and grant products and features;  
(ii)  disbursement policies and procedures;  
(iii)  country- and project-specific case studies and group discussion;  
(iv)  preparation, submission, and monitoring of loan withdrawal applications;  
(v)  project accounting and monitoring compliance;  
(vi)  government counterpart fund contributions and accounting systems; and  
(vii)  general audit issues for the ADB projects in the DMC concerned. 
   
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $300,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency;  CTL  will  implement  the  TA.  The  expected 
commencement date is February 2013 and expected completion date is December 2014. The 
TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with the  Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
14.  The resource speakers and targeted participants are mentioned in para. 10. 
 
15.  The  average  duration  of each  seminar  is  expected  to  be 2 days. However, longer 
duration can be coordinated by CTL and the government concerned. There will be an average 
of around 30 participants for each seminar to allow effective participation and discussion. More 
participants may be requested by the government in coordination with CTL. Seminars may be 
carried out more than once a year in the DMC based on geographical location and spread. 
Smaller workshops may be carried out based on the request of the DMC and in coordination 
with CTL.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for 
the Investment Loan and Grant Disbursement Seminars for Developing Member Countries, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
